greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: List of fixed polyominoes in binary coding, ordered by number of bits, then value of the binary code. Can be read as irregular table with row lengths A001168.
comment: The binary coding (as suggested in a post to the SeqFan list by F. T. Adams-Watters) is obtained by summing the powers of 2 corresponding to the numbers covered by the polyomino, when the points of the quarter-plane are numbered by antidiagonals, and the animal is pushed to both borders as to obtain the smallest possible value. See example for further details.

The smallest value for an n-omino is the sum 2^0+...+2^(n-1) = 2^n-1 = A000225(n), and the largest value, obtained for the straight n-omino in y direction, is 2^0+2^2+2^5+...+2^(A000217(n)-1) = A246534(n).
link: John Mason, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..50149
F. T. Adams-Watters, Re: Sequence proposal by John Mason, SeqFan list, Aug 24 2014
example: Number the points of the first quadrant as follows:
The "empty" 0-omino is represented by the empty sum equal to 0 = a(1).
The monomino is represented by a square on 0, and the binary code 2^0 = 1 = a(2).
The two fixed dominos are ".." and ":", represented by 2^0+2^1 = 3 = a(3) and 2^0+2^2 = 5 = a(4).

The A001168(3) = 6 fixed triominoes are represented by 2^0+2^1+2^3 = 11 (...), 2^0+2^1+2^2 = 7 (:.), 2^0+2^1+2^4 =19 (.:), ..., 2^0+2^2+2^5 = 37; again these 6 values are listed in increasing size as a(5),..., a(10).
program: (PARI) grow(L,N=[],D=[[1,0],[0,1],[-1,0],[0,-1]])={ for(i=1,#L,for(j=1,#P=L[i],for(k=1,#P,for(d=1,#D, vecmin(P[k]+D[d])<0 && P-=vector(#P,i,D[d])/*shift if needed*/; !setsearch(P,P[k]+D[d]) && N=setunion([setunion([P[k]+D[d]],P)],N); P!=L[i] && P+=vector(#P,i,D[d])/*undo...*/))));if(N,N,[[[0,0]]])}
xref: See A246521 and A246559 for enumeration of free and one-sided polyominoes.
results.author: _M. F. Hasler_, Aug 28 2014
